content.description: Climb the gully to the right of Second Hand.  Will lead you to the Aerosmith belay.  Good moderate.

To reach the start.  Either climb Love Potion, Dream Landscape, Funky Finger Crack, or the start of Leaning Tower Direct and traverse over to the belay station.  Then climb up under the roof and clip the upgraded bolts.  Awesome exposure.  1st bolt is hidden and can be difficult to see.  A bit loose, but it looks worse than it is.
content.protection: 3 bolts, supplement with standard gear.  No fixed anchor.

content.description: Take the low-angle corner left of Noname up to a ledge below a blank wall, 10 feet up, traverse right to easy rock.
content.location: Left side of the Tower past Arrowsmith.  Scramble off to the south.

content.description: Begin 10 feet left of the cedar tree, which is in front of the cave below Captain Crunch.  Move up and right to find good holds and pro.  Make the sustained moves up the severely overhanging traverse to a small ledge.  Right side of the ledge you will find a bolt.  Move up on more sustained moves to a stance just right of the Captain Crunch start.
content.protection: First pro takes 2 #1 TCU's and a 2.5 Friend.  One bolt + #1 Friend. Gear anchor.

content.description: Left of the Y, start off on easy climbing with good edges.  Then look right for the big hueco pocket that you will traverse over to (crux).  Then good face holds with a few laybacks of the crack above lead into the slab section.  Take it straight up for the extra spice of the run out face moves, or the easier line keeps to the crack stepping up on the final ledges.
content.location: Left of Arrowsmith.  Scramble down to the south.

content.description: Climbs a clean short finger crack or the corner to the left of 'the Y'.
content.location: Left hand side of the Tower.  Past Arrowsmith.  Scramble down the south side.

climbs.name: Neckline
climbs.fa: Donnie Hunt, Duane Raleigh, Bill Thomas 1980

content.description: Scramble 20 into the first gully, around 150 feet left of LTD.  Climb the short chimney up the right side to a large ledge.  Above, you'll find an arching crack that ends below a steep headwall where you traverse let into a yellow corner with some loose rock up to the top.

Climb the main ramp using gear and then move up the face following the bolts. The crux is just past the 2nd bolt in my opinion.  For top roping I suggest using the middle balcony to belay instead of the lower section, a much better view too.
content.protection: Gear, 3 bolts, and a small TCU placement in a crack on the face.  Chains up top.
content.location: The center middle ramp on the Leaning tower.  Look for the large diving board up top which you will be to the right of.

content.description: Climb to a 2 bolt stance starting near the Aerosmith landing.  Climb 20' up and right to find the hidden bolt.  Use a long draw or sling to limit rope drag.  Move sharply to the left using thin ledges to avoid the steep overhangs to gain the upper crack.  Follow the steep and exposed crack to the top.
content.protection: nuts and cams to 3 inches, retrobolted, Very scary pro

content.description: Climbing the lower slab section is the real crux.  Some thin moves on small gear, then the crack opens back up and leads to a belay stance in the corner (mid to large gear), then up the chimney section up and exit right.
content.protection: .5"-2" gear on the lower slab.  Good Nuts.  Take a fatty for the chimney section up top.  A #4 Camalot is handy!
content.location: From the primary base area below Leaning Tower.  Follow the trail up and left and then scramble through some ledges to the right until your below the main ramp of Leaning Tower.  The route follows the the left facing corner all the way up the tower.

content.description: Very exposed and scary start. Hand traversing from right to left across a steep wall to the start of the crack. Get your #1 TCU in and then start up the funky crack. More face climbing than crack.
content.protection: many wired nuts and small cams from 0.2 to 2 inches. def. need a #1 TCU or equivalent

content.description: This takes the direct line to the first belay station for Neckline.  Start between Arrowsmith and Funky Finger Crack.

climbs.name: Doctor Kildare
climbs.fa: Duane Raleigh, Jon Frank, Mark Herndon, Jimmy Ratzlaff 1980

content.description: It is a short verticle, right-facing corner which leads into a long horizontal roof with a small undercling crack.
content.location: This ankle-breaking route is on the very right-hand, lower side of the Tower.

content.description: Start Captian Crunch and then move out off the ramp up onto the face where the bolts begin.  The thin face moves are nice.
content.protection: Optional gear and then three bolts to protect the face.  Gear anchor.

content.description: Broken corner 25 feet left of 'Tight Rope'.  Climb up black rock 20 feet into a corner and follow it or the crack to the top.
content.location: The far left side of the tower.  Just to the right of the scramble off.

climbs.name: Captain Crunch
climbs.fa: Ken Rose, Kenny Sterns 1974/ Direct Finish in 1979 by Jon Frank, Jimmy Ratzliff

content.description: Climb the super easy right most ramp up to a short roof section and belay in the boulders up top.
content.protection: Rack to 2.5", gear anchor.  Watch for loose of falling rock.
content.location: The right most ramp on the wall.  Scramble across the ledges below to get to the base of this climb.

content.description:
This is an alternative pitch-2 of Arrowsmith. Here's the name sake: 

  "Arrowsmith" looks like a question mark '?'. Its P1 straight and its P2 curled. "The Y" is an alternative P1 of "Arrowsmith". Together they form an upside-down lowercase 'y': Lowercase because their P2 is curled. "Capital Y" as an alternative P2 is straight up: Thus making an upside-down capital 'Y'. You'll need to look at the topo to make sense of the name. To get there, climb P1 of Arrowsmith or The Y. Belay. Then instead of the traditional P2 where you start by traverse right. You'd climb straight up and slightly to the left along a crack system 25ft to a triangular cove roomy enough to lie down. From the cove, you continue 35ft straight up and slightly to the left along the cracks -- this time you'll see two cracks leading to the top and they are about 5ft apart. Follow either crack. Once on the top and on the flat ground, walk back 15ft to wrap your rope around any big boulders -- that's your top anchor. Belay.
content.protection: Our rack has DB stoppers #3-13, CAMP tricams #0.5-5. We had DB C3's but did not need them for Capital Y.
content.location: Bushwack off a gulley to the left (south) of Leaning Tower.

content.description: Great climb with some nice friction opportunities.  Sometimes you can even get in a little chimneying in.
content.location:
The left side of Leaning tower.  If you follow the trail a little to the left you will find big slab and nice spot to lace up.  Climb up to the corner and set a belay.  The second pitch has a couple of options that are really not very good. 

  Scramble off to the south or rap at Lycra sheath (not recommended unless your TRing it).

content.description: Some really good lines go up the centerpiece of the Narrows.  With it's signature diving board formation, it is easy to recognize.
